awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Integrated Onboard Charger and Auxiliary Power Module for Electric Vehicles
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to design and develop an integrated charger for electric vehicle applications. Electric vehicles produce less than half the emissions of conventional combustion engine vehicles. This project develops a new integrated onboard charger and auxiliary power module for electric vehicles.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project advances an integrated onboard charger for electric vehicles. Currently, all the upcoming and commercially available electric vehicles are equipped with an individual onboard charger to charge traction batteries and an additional auxiliary power module to power auxiliary loads. This project develops a new topology, design, control, thermal management, packaging, and validation of the first integrated charger onboard and auxiliary power module for electric vehicles. Systems engineering tasks include: optimize the converter design, implement a closed-loop controller, conduct a thermal management study, conduct reliability analyses, design the enclosure, and demonstrate automotive-level functionality requirements.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Through this SBIR Phase II project, AmpX Technologies, Inc. has accomplished the design, optimization, development and in-vehicle demonstration of an integrated combo onboard charger with auxiliary power module for next-generation electric vehicles, which is the main intellectual merit of this project. The award outcomes include (1) Development of two prototypes, AXT400 and AXT800, for 400V vehicle and 800V vehicle respectively with complete systematic, electrical, firmware and mechanical designs; (2) Development of a comprehensive and effective control and optimization software platform to analyze and design various power converters with enhanced efficiency and performance; (3) Extended design of combo chargers specified for different vehicle specs for further commercialization and mass production. The AXT800 prototype has been successfully equipped and demonstrated for full functionalities on an electric vehicle. This integration achieves significant weight reduction over 50lbs from the onboard power conversion units to this vehicle.

Widespread adoption of electric vehicles will significantly reduce emissions from the transportation sector. Electric vehicles have higher energy efficiencies in comparison to their internal combustion engine counterparts; however, the electrical power conversion systems of EVs are still expensive, large, heavy and in some cases redundant. The broader impacts of this project include facilitating widespread adoption of electric vehicles through reducing weight, volume, and manufacturing cost of electric vehicles. This project demonstrated an innovative way to reduce the size and weight of the onboard charging components in electric cars, and further reduces the manufacturing cost which will in turn help the United States to be at the forefront of the emerging electric vehicle technologies.  It will also lead to creating more jobs around the technology in the US with continued commercialization process. 


Last Modified: 05/20/2024
Modified by: Zeyu Zhang
